```{r setup, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
# Data
service_pop <- data.frame(
  Population = factor(c("> 10,000", "1,000 - 10,000", "< 1,000"),
                     levels = c("> 10,000", "1,000 - 10,000", "< 1,000")),
  Percentage = c(33, 48, 20)
)

# Bar chart
bar_chart <- ggplot(service_pop, aes(x = Population, y = Percentage)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", 
          fill = c("#B8DFF0", "#4682B4", "#1C4E80")) +
  geom_text(aes(label = paste0(Percentage, "%")), 
            hjust = -0.2) +
  coord_flip() +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 55), 
                    breaks = seq(0, 50, by = 10),
                    labels = paste0(seq(0, 50, by = 10), "%")) +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Utilities by Service\nPopulation (n=483)",
       x = "Service Population",
       y = "Percent of Responding Utilities") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold", margin = margin(b = 15)),
    axis.title.x = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title.y = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.margin = margin(20, 40, 20, 20)
  )

# Save as pdf
ggsave("bar_chart.pdf", bar_chart, width = 6, height = 3.5)
```

```{r echo=FALSE}
# Data
base_charge <- data.frame(
  ServicePopulation = factor(c("25,000+", "10,000-24,999", "5,000-9,999", "2,500-4,999", "1,000-2,499", "1-999"),
                             levels = c("25,000+", "10,000-24,999", "5,000-9,999", "2,500-4,999", "1,000-2,499", "1-999")),
  Water = c(25, 22, 20, 18, 15, 10),
  Sewer = c(27, 24, 21, 19, 17, 12)
)

# Convert to Long Format
library(tidyr)
base_charge_long <- pivot_longer(base_charge, cols = c(Water, Sewer), names_to = "ServiceType", values_to = "Charge")

# Plot
chart <- ggplot(base_charge_long, aes(x = ServicePopulation, y = Charge, fill = ServiceType)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge", width = 0.7) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#4682B4", "gray")) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Median Monthly Base Charge Amounts by Service Population",
       x = "Service Population", y = "Median Monthly Base Charge") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    legend.title = element_blank()
  )

# Save as pdf
ggsave("base_charge_chart.pdf", plot = chart, width = 4.8, height = 7)
```

```{r echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}

# Data
uniform_data <- data.frame(
  x = c(0, 20),
  y = c(3, 3)
)

# Data for segments
increasing_segments <- data.frame(
  x = c(0, 5, 10),         # start x
  xend = c(5, 10, 20),     # end x
  y = c(2, 4, 6),          # y values
  yend = c(2, 4, 6)        # same y values for horizontal lines
)

decreasing_segments <- data.frame(
  x = c(0, 5, 10),         # start x
  xend = c(5, 10, 20),     # end x
  y = c(4, 3, 2),          # y values
  yend = c(4, 3, 2)        # same y values for horizontal lines
)

# Common theme settings
common_theme <- theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.major = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.line = element_line(color = "black"),
    plot.margin = margin(t = 20, r = 20, b = 20, l = 20)
  )

# Uniform Rate Plot
uniform_plot <- ggplot(uniform_data, aes(x, y)) +
  geom_line(color = "darkgreen", size = 1) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 6, 2), limits = c(0, 6), 
                    labels = scales::dollar) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 20, 5), limits = c(0, 20)) +
  labs(title = "UNIFORM", x = "kgals", y = "rate") +
  common_theme

# Increasing Block Rate Plot
increasing_plot <- ggplot() +
  geom_segment(data = increasing_segments,
              aes(x = x, xend = xend, y = y, yend = yend),
              color = "darkgreen", size = 1) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 6, 2), limits = c(0, 6),
                    labels = scales::dollar) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 20, 5), limits = c(0, 20)) +
  labs(title = "INCREASING BLOCK", x = "kgals", y = "rate") +
  common_theme

# Decreasing Block Rate Plot
decreasing_plot <- ggplot() +
  geom_segment(data = decreasing_segments,
              aes(x = x, xend = xend, y = y, yend = yend),
              color = "darkgreen", size = 1) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 6, 2), limits = c(0, 6),
                    labels = scales::dollar) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 20, 5), limits = c(0, 20)) +
  labs(title = "DECREASING BLOCK", x = "kgals", y = "rate") +
  common_theme

# Save plots
ggsave("uniform_rate.pdf", plot = uniform_plot, width = 2.6, height = 2.6)
ggsave("increasing_block.pdf", plot = increasing_plot, width = 2.6, height = 2.6)
ggsave("decreasing_block.pdf", plot = decreasing_plot, width = 2.6, height = 2.6)
```

```{=latex}
        % Paragraph 1
        {\fontsize{14pt}{18pt}\selectfont
        In addition to fixed charges, most rate structures also include a volumetric charge. Unlike fixed charges, volumetric charges vary month-to-month based on consumption. Three common ways to charge for volume are uniform, increasing block, and decreasing block rates.}\\[0.8cm] % Increased spacing between paragraphs

        % Paragraph 2
        {\fontsize{14pt}{18pt}\selectfont
        With a \textbf{uniform rate} structure, customers are charged a constant rate per unit, i.e., the rate does not change as the customer consumes more.}\\[0.8cm]

        % Paragraph 3
        {\fontsize{14pt}{18pt}\selectfont
        In an \textbf{increasing block rate} structure, the rate increases as the customer uses more. This structure is often employed by utilities that want to explicitly encourage or signal conservation by making higher volumes of consumption more expensive.}\\[0.8cm]

        % Paragraph 4
        {\fontsize{14pt}{18pt}\selectfont
        Utilities may also structure their rates so that the rate per unit decreases at higher levels of consumption; this type of block rate is called a \textbf{decreasing block structure}. This type of rate structure may be used in cases where the utility wants to encourage economic development and attract high consuming customers.}
    };
```

```{r echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(ggtext)

# Setting up common theme

 theme(
   panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
   axis.title.x = element_blank(),
   legend.position = "right",
   plot.title = element_markdown(size = 11),
   legend.title = element_text(size = 10),
   legend.text = element_text(size = 9)
 )

# water bill plot
p1 <- ggplot(water_data, aes(x = fiscal_year, y = price, group = category, color = category)) +

 scale_color_manual(values = c("inside" = "#B7D9F2", "outside" = "#1F4E78")) +
 labs(title = "Median Monthly <b>Water</b> Bill<br>Inside vs. Outside 2022-2024",
      y = "Median monthly price $") +
 scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 100), breaks = seq(0, 100, 25)) +
 my_theme

# wastewater bill plot
p2 <- ggplot(wastewater_data, aes(x = fiscal_year, y = price, group = category, color = category)) +

 labs(title = "Median Monthly <b>Wastewater</b> Bill<br>Inside vs. Outside 2022-2024",
```

```{r echo=FALSE, eval = FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
# First plot data
data1 <- data.frame(
  population = factor(c("< 1,000", "1,000 - 10,000", "> 10,000"),
                     levels = c("< 1,000", "1,000 - 10,000", "> 10,000")),
  above = c(38, 116, 90),
  below = c(10, 12, 4)
) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(above, below),
               names_to = "type",
               values_to = "value")

# Second plot data
data2 <- data.frame(
  population = factor(c("< 1,000", "1,000 - 10,000", "> 10,000"),
                     levels = c("< 1,000", "1,000 - 10,000", "> 10,000")),
  above = c(12, 62, 74),
  below = c(36, 66, 20)
) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(above, below),
               names_to = "type",
               values_to = "value")


legend_data <- data.frame(
  type = c("below", "above"),  
  label = c("Operating Revenue < Operating Expense", 
            "Operating Revenue >= Operating Expense")
)

# Create plot
legend <- ggplot() +
  geom_rect(data = legend_data, 
            aes(xmin = 0, xmax = 0.2, 
                ymin = 1:2 - 0.3, ymax = 1:2 + 0.3,
                fill = type)) +
  geom_text(data = legend_data,
            aes(x = 0.3, y = 1:2, 
                label = label),
            hjust = 0,
            size = 6) +  
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("below" = "#CCCCCC", 
                              "above" = "#4CAF50")) +
  xlim(0, 4) +
  ylim(0.5, 2.5) +
  theme_void() +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

# Create first plot
chart1 <- ggplot(data1, aes(x = population, y = value, fill = type)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("above" = "#4CAF50", "below" = "#CCCCCC")) +
  geom_text(aes(label = value),
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5),
            size = 6) +  
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 150), breaks = seq(0, 150, 50)) +
  labs(
    title = "Proportion of Utilities with 2023 Operating\nRatio >= 1, Excluding Depreciation (n = 329 utilities)",
    x = "Service Population",
    y = "Number of Utilities"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),  
    axis.title = element_text(size = 16), 
    axis.text = element_text(size = 14),   
    legend.position = "none"
  )

# Create second plot
chart2 <- ggplot(data2, aes(x = population, y = value, fill = type)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("above" = "#4CAF50", "below" = "#CCCCCC")) +
  geom_text(aes(label = value),
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5),
            size = 6) + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 150), breaks = seq(0, 150, 50)) +
  labs(
    title = "Proportion of Utilities with 2023 Cost\nRecovery >= 1, Including Depreciation (n = 329 utilities)",
    x = "Service Population",
    y = "Number of Utilities"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),  
    axis.title = element_text(size = 16),  
    axis.text = element_text(size = 14),   
    legend.position = "none"
  )

# Combine two plots
combined_plot <- grid.arrange(
  legend,
  chart1,
  chart2,
  ncol = 1,
  heights = c(0.2, 1, 1)
)

# Save as pdf
ggsave("operating_ratio_charts.pdf", combined_plot, width = 8, height = 12, units = "in")
```

```{=latex}
    \vspace{0.8cm}
    {\fontsize{13pt}{19pt}\selectfont\bfseries
    WHAT IS OPERATING RATIO?}
    
    \vspace{0.7cm}
    {\fontsize{14pt}{17pt}\selectfont
    The operating ratio, also known as the cost recovery ratio, is a financial benchmark that determines if an entity is operating at a loss, gain, or just breaking even. The ratio is simply the division of operating revenues by operating expenses, which can include or exclude depreciation. A utility's operating ratio must be at least 1.0 to break even.}
    
    \vspace{0.8cm}
    {\fontsize{13pt}{19pt}\selectfont\bfseries
    WHY INCLUDE DEPRECIATION?}
    
    \vspace{0.7cm}
    {\fontsize{14pt}{17pt}\selectfont
    Whenever possible, depreciation should be included in operating expenses to account for the inevitable cost of replacing equipment and infrastructure at the end of its expected useful life. Depreciation allows costs to be figuratively parceled out over time, avoiding a sudden, and enormous expense when the time comes to replace assets.}
};

      align=justify]
at ([xshift=0.52\paperwidth,yshift=-1.6in]current page.north west) {
```
